title.narrative: Early Childhood Development Program for Children Affected by HIV/AIDS

description.narrative: Children Affected by HIV,Family members,People living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA),Community Volunteer,Staff,Community Health Worker

The 3 year grant would support an expanded program to reach a total of 12,446 children under six and 7,070 families through 53 ECD Centers. During our current 2012-2013 grant implementation period, Episcopal Relief & Development and our partner the Zambia Anglican Council (ZAC) established a community-based, volunteer-driven Early Childhood Development Program in three provinces, involving 8,000 children under five and their caregivers (CGs) affected by HIV/AIDS. The holistic program built on the assets and programs of our faith-based organization at the national, regional and local levels. There is now a thriving network of ECD Centers housed in schools and churches in rural Zambia – with ECD volunteers working with caregiver support & learning groups and children’s playgroups, combined with home visits and coordinated services. The Essential Package’s Visual Guides and other tools form the basis of the program, integrated with child health, nutrition, and livelihoods strengthening. The ECD Program is also serving as a catalyst for community organizing and development in these marginalized areas. With its holistic design, volunteer structure, referrals and linkages, the ECD Program has shown signs of success in helping caregivers and communities so that young children can thrive in very challenging rural areas. Based on this strong foundation, over the next three years we propose to expand the program by serving additional families at the current centers and by integrating the ECD program into our community development work in other high HIV prevalence areas in other provinces. With lessons learned from the first twenty months’ implementation, we will improve the project design and its impact (see section v, page 8 for specific quality improvements) The current program is managed by two ZAC field offices in six project sites in 3 provinces. In one of these project sites, Chibombo district, we leveraged unused ECD Centers constructed by Plan International that had been left with the communities when Plan International’s funding for its ECD program ended. However, as Plan International has just received funding through UNICEF, the plan is now for Episcopal Relief & Development/ZAC to transfer the 8 ECD Centers and their activities to Plan who will take over the management and reporting via UNICEF. As Chibombo is close to the capital there are many NGOs working in the district, so by transferring the sites to Plan, Episcopal Relief & Development & ZAC will be able to start ECD programs in more neglected areas such as Luapula and Southern provinces. Therefore, we will continue and expand services in four current sites and integrate ECD into programs managed by the other three of ZAC’s five field offices, setting up 15 new ECD-Center based programs in 12 rural project sites
